Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 05:59AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Another viewpoint. My sister, Sue, died from breast cancer at 52 (2005).  Everyone (excpet my Mom) in my mother's family has died from cancers.  Sue was offered the test but she opted not to have it done.  One of her concerns was if it would affect her daughter's ability to get medical insurance. During that time my GP asked me if I wanted to get tested but since I didn't have BC I figured why bother.  Just keep going and getting the mammos. If Sue or myself had been tested (I'm sure she would have been positive) than I'm sure they would have sent me off to have an MRI well before the cancer I have reached stage 3.  It's the one regret that I have. Now that I'm dx'ed, my mother (who has had stage 1 twice) and I said we had enough.  We had to know for the rest of the family.  We both tested positive BRCA 2.  We've shared this with the immediate family and with the cousins.  It felt like a relief for us.  We knew there was a reason for all the cancer and to be able to blame this mutation feels good. My 30 year old daughter will be going in to be tested in the next week or so --  she's already met with the counselor.  She's still thinking through what she wants to do if she positive.  But she's already in a high risk category anway so the gene doesn't make a huge difference.  She's leaning toward the idea of doing vigilant screening till at least 40.  Then see what the medical world has to offer for options at that time.

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 08:28AM AnacortesGirl wrote: many - I completely understand your anxiety.  But it is very good news that the PET scan did not show any areas other than the breast and axilliary nodes.  PET scans are highly sensitive and can show areas of potential cancer before the mass has become large enough to be visible mass on a CT scan.  All the research has shown that FEC followed by taxol or taxotere is a very effective regimen.  And the real kicker for us that are ER/PR positive is the hormonal therapies using tamoxifen and/or one of the aromatase inhibitors have significantly cut done the chances of recurrence by as much as 25-30%. I know you referenced the ACS website in another post.  If you are looking at their survival stats they show stage IIIc somewhere around a 50% chance of no mets in the first 5 years.  Well the oncs that I have talked to and the more recent studies put our chances of mets around 75% for the first 5 years.  Odds for us have gotten much better! Believe in the treatment!  Your wife has a good plan in place.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2013 10:19AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Another twist is androgens. There are different androgens but one of them is testosterone. My onc had my bone and liver biopsy tested for androgen receptors. The liver was positive and the bone was variable. So we have identified another treatment option. When the time is right (like when the Xeloda quits working) then he will put me on a anti-androgen called Casodex. It is the exact same concept of the anti-estrogen treatments but using the male hormone that exists in our bodies. And just like some tumor are ER+, some of our tumors are also Androgen positive. This is an off label treatment so he said I would probably have to buy the drug on my own. But he said one of his male prostrate cancer patients found it at Costco for $30 a month. I'll gladly pay that!

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 08:35AM AnacortesGirl wrote: i'm BRCA2+ so my onc sent me to a gynecologist onc that specializes in genetic cancers. She gave me the choice of whether to have just the ovaries out or both ovaries and uterus.  I choose to keep my uterus because it wasn't causing any problems and we didn't anticipate any issues since tamoxifen wasn't going to be a big player in terms of treatment.  I wanted to leave it in since it is part of the support structure in the lower abdomen.  No regrets in the past 4 years. What she did make clear was that I was not getting just an oophorectomy.  That is simply the removal of the ovaries.  At least for BRCA ladies, it is very important that the Fallopian tubes come out also.  The shorthand name is BSO.  The longhand is bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2013 07:48AM AnacortesGirl wrote: As a general rule the CA 27.29 is used to follow breast cancer and the CA 15.3 to follow the gynecologic (sp??) cancers such as ovarian and uterine. I don't think it is uncommon for oncs, if they track tumor markers at all because some don't use them, to follow a couple markers. My onc uses CA 27.29 and CEA. The TM that your onc chooses is not related to ER+ or ER-. Lobular (which I have) has a higher risk of going to other places than bone, liver, lungs and brain. A couple of years ago I found a study that showed the percentages for where lobular goes but I don't think I saved the link. If I'm remembering correctly, the next most likely place was the peritoneum, ovaries, fallopian areas. Or that could be my BRCA + mutation talking -- I'm not sure. Anyway, it could be that your onc is finding a better correlation between your how your bones mets are doing with the CA 15,3 marker. Or he is just watching it in case there is a spike and indicates the mets may have moved to a different area. As for dropping the CA 27.29, it could be that it doesn't correlate with your bone mets and he doesn't find it useful. If the tumor markers move around a lot then the trend line would be a big zig zag yet your scans show that your bone mets are stable. That would be an example of the TM not correlating to your mets. This is not unusual. That is why some docs don't even use TMs. Ever. But the best thing would be to ask your onc about your tumor markers. I'm doing a lot of supposition but I'm sure your onc has a good reason for which markers he is following. Make a commitment to ask him at your next visit and don't let him leave the room until he has explained it so that you understand his logic.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 11:20PM AnacortesGirl wrote: AnnAlive - I was never given a punch biopsy even though I had significant thickening and redness.  In my case the thickening had to do with the nature of invasive lobular cancer.  I made the skin very thick and the overall breast felt very hard.  The redness would wax and wane.  The response from my oncs was that edema (swelling) is not unusual during chemo so that was why I would see a change in the skin color.  It was about 4 months into chemo before my breast finally softemed amd the redness went away. It could be that you also have lobular cancer.  It is not unusual to have both.  And they are treated the same.  Another possibility is that your tissue's fluid pathways have changed due to the reduction in the tumor and they can't drain as readily.  Surgery will be the answer to your questions.  I wish you the best!

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2009 08:17AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Merry, I agree about the dark cloud.  It was very dark for me for the moment I awoke from biopsy and the surgeon said I'm sorry but it looks like cancer.  It was 5 weeks before I finally started chemo.  Although part of me was frustrated because it took so long to get treatment started I needed a lot of that time to continue to come to grips with what was going on and getting myself mentally ready.  One of the things I did was look on the site at the women who had already gone through tx.  There are so, so many of them and they are doing so well.  Honestly, when I heard the dx I figured I was doomed.  We have breast cancer in my family so my thoughts went to what had happened in the past.  But the more I talked to my onc about my fears and what I read from these women the better I felt.  It's an absolute fact that not only has the treatments gotten better in how it affects the cancer but all the supportive meds to help through chemo have made it so much better.  I did a lot of talking during that time.  I had to get the words and thoughts out; the talking helped clear my mind.  It also increased my resolve.  Other women have done this; so can I. You already have some positives.  They know what the cancer is -- that means they know how to fight it.  They found the lymph nodes -- they took them out so there is no wondering if something is still lurking in those nodes.  Grade 3 is aggressive but the great thing about that is it's also more receptive to the chemo.  You got surgery first and the tumor is out. That last comment might seem obvious but it really is meaningful.  I don't often mention this but I had some indicators that have caused the onc to feel I need the chemo first.  That they couldn't wait until I had surgery and had healed.  But I've had 12 weeks of chemo so far and now, everyday, that dark cloud keeping getting a little smaller.  It's not straight over my head any more.  And it's a reminder that other women have done this and that I will continue.  Every year the treatments and drugs have improved.  We're going to blow away those old stats and when they tally us it's going to look pretty darn positive. Keeping talking.  Some of those fears and concerns are valid; others are just our emotions talking.  But as you get those out of the way you'll find your strength and you'll find that you can do this.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2010 08:09AM AnacortesGirl wrote: All - Waiting is tough, really tough.  It's the hardest part.  sas14 - I understand when you say that you are a numbers person -- I like my data.  But that isn't to our advantage in the waiting stage when you don't know if it is bc or not.  The odds really don't matter if it's 10% or 90%.  The results that will tell you what you really want to know. Lisa1962 and CinD both have good advice.  As weird as it may sound, getting back the news that you have cancer is better than not knowing.  Once you know, you feel like you can move on with your life.  I had to wait a month from initial mammo to path report.  With a strong family history (mom & sis) that waiting period could have put me in the loony bin.  But the way I looked at it, cancer was not a confirmed diagnosis and I was not going to let it rule my life until proven otherwise.  Yep, I was worried, but went on the things that Lisa1962 suggested and I kept control of my life. You'll get through this - it's hard, but keep your faith! mikie513 & kittygriffin - I'm so sorry for your diagnosis.  I'm glad to see you discovered the forums and are getting support from all the great ladies.  This place has been great for me.  The information overload and waiting that comes with the initial diagnosis is so overwhelming! As hard as it is, please keep waiting until the surgery, path reports and any scan results come back before trying to find out more.  There are different types of breast cancers and many, many different situations.  You need to understand your own presentation so you understand what you don't have. Based on what you've posted here it appears to me that you ladies have been doing the right thing and caught this very early.  Treatment is so much easier and the prognosis is excellent.  Wishing both of you the very best.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 08:30AM AnacortesGirl wrote: My thoughts about crying is that it's the mind's way of cleaning the system of all the negatives.  It's a good thing.  But sometimes we are so overwhelmed that we still are see all the things that are wrong -- the tears just aren't cleaning the windows in our mind like they should.  If that is the case then I believe you should talk to your onc about something to help you through the depressing thoughts.   I can see in your posts that you're normally a positive person.  But you've also recognized that there is some sort of emotional cycle going on that hits in the afternoons.  If you can figure out a way to move past that without drugs then that would be great.  If not, then maybe the support of an anti-depressant to aid the process might be a good thing.  For me, the emotional rollercoaster hit about halfway through my first 12 weeks of chemo.  One of my personal insights was that I needed to take more time for myself.  I really admire the women who can maintain such full days with work, kids at home and other activities.  I finally accepted the fact each of us is different and that I needed to do a better job listening to my own body.  So if I wake up and feel lousy (either emotionally or physically) then I take a disability day.  I would love to be stronger and be a super woman.  But all I am doing is adding more stress by giving myself expectations that will cost me too high a price in the long run.  It was hard to accept this because I was always the lead and strongest team member.  You know, the one who got the high ranking?  Well, now I'm sitting back and letting some of those other people shine and now I'm realizing it's a good thing for both them and me.

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2012 09:26AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Here is what I have learned about bone mets at this point. There are two types: lytic and blastic. It is normal for our bones to continuously build new bone cells and dissolve the old ones. Lytic mets weaken the bone -- the osteoclasts bone cells have been activated and these are the cells that dissolve bone. Blastic mets are a buildup of bone -- the osteoblastic cells are being motivated to continuously build new bone. Bone scans see blastic mets. CTs see lytic mets. In my case I have both and my onc told me that this is why he orders both of these scans. I also ran across a study that claimed PET/CT was slightly better than the combination of a bone scan and a CT. The PET part of the scan will see high glucose activity where there are cancer cells regardless of the lesion being lytic or blastic. Personally, I'm not fond of the PET just because I have had quite a few and ran into false-positives. Based on some of the posts by other it also seems like there are good reasons to use other tests such as MRIs since they can also reveal things like arthritis. Don't know that any one test is the "right" one. But just wanted to let you know that there are different types and not all tests show both types.

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2013 07:43AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Didn't you go to MD Anderson for a consult at one point? My memory isn't so good so I might have that wrong. I'm thinking it would be beneficial to get another opinion from an onc who specializes/researches the BRCA cancers. I'm sure that is why the Mayo onc wants to keep you on carbo - because of the effectiveness that has been seen with the platinum chemos against the BRCA cancers. But I don't have a good knowledge about carbo and the potential effects on the kidneys. I also wonder if there would be some further testing done at MD Anderson to look at your cancer genome to determine if targeted therapies such as affinitor would be effective based on your mTor pathway inhibitors. When I hear kidney I also think of when I was on the trial with Sutent. Very similiar to Avastin and is used for renal cancers. It is an antiogenisis agent that is supposed to prevent the cancer from creating blood pathways. I guess what I'm saying is that a third onc consult with an onc who is really in tune with some of the leading edge tools to try and determine the therapy that would have the highest likelihood of success while minimizing risks. I've been thinking about you and was just about to send a PM when I saw your post. I'm sorry that you have been taken off the trial. I am finishing up my first month tomorrow (actually today since it's like 4:00 am) but I'm just seeing the nurse practitioner and not the onc. Otherwise I'd be asking her about ABT-888 and if she has seen adverse effects on the kidney and what direction she would take. It's a rough decision. Rads can do damage -- no doubt about that. Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2012 11:49AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I was still having periods at age 50 when I started chemo. After 3 months on chemo my periods finally quit and didn't come back after I was done with chemo. The only issue I had (have) are the hot flashes. I always wondered if I had gone through menopause naturally if I would have had any issues at all since my periods never gave me any problems (other than being out of feminine products at the wrong times!). Since I was BRCA2+ we felt an oomph was important. My surgeon gave me the option to also remove the uterus at the same time. She is a gynecology surgeon who specializes in hereditary cancers. She didn't have any preference so it was up to me. I chose not to remove the uterus because I had heard of too many women who had prolapse issues from removing the organ. It could be that these were the older type of hysterectomy surgeries that were more prone to organ prolapse -- I'm not really sure. There is a good website for learning more about hysterectomies and helping decide if that is the route you would like to take. It's called HysterSisters. All I know is that nothing changed between the chemopause and after the oomph. The only symptom was hot flashes. And the hot flashes get worse for me on certain meds such as Aromasin. Not quite as bad when I've been on Femara or Tamoxifen.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2013 11:14AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I'm not sure why your onc is saying that there is no way to tell. With a PET/CT you have two views. The CT will show the lesion, whether it is cancerous or just the damaged remains. But the PET will show the uptake if it is cancerous and if it just the damaged remains then there is no glucose uptake so the indicates no cancer.
Posts.Title: Bone mets...I don't get it. raro DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2013 11:41AM AnacortesGirl wrote: My understanding is that it is the amount of uptake that indicates normal versus abnormal. Cancer cells grow faster than normal bone cells so although the glucose uptake is going to be there for healing bone cells, it is going to be less than the glucose uptake for cancerous cells. Having said that, this is one of the reasons that PET scans are prone to false-positives. Back when I was involved in a study of the usefulness of PET in following the effectiveness of breast cancer treatment it seemed that every PET would show something new that could indicate mets (I was stage III at the time). And each time the new finding would end up being nothing of concern. So there can be many reasons for an elevated uptake. But if the met has been followed with a PET/CT from the beginning I believe it is easier for the radiologist to discern between normal and abnormal. But I'm not a radiologist or a tech. So I could be all washed up in what I'm saying. It's just from my experience in being scanned and talking to my onc. I have not been NED since I was dx'ed with mets, only after I completed my stage III treatment.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2010 05:20AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I'm so sorry about your diagnosis.  It is such a shock to hear the words breast cancer and then hear the words stage 3.  I've been there.  But the silver lining in a stage 3 dx is that you get the Full Monty - you'll get all the treatments to eradicate the cancer from your body.  And you'll find that the treatments nowadays are very successful.  We have lots of women 5+ years out of treatment who have no signs of cancer.  When your ready, read the "Stage 3 Five Years+ Out-Check In!" topic and you'll hear about some of these ladies who graciously come back to give encouragement to people like you and I who are going through treatments. I'm going to the onc today and will either get my last chemo tx or we'll decide that I'm done.  I've been on neoadjuvant chemo to shrink the tumors and get rid of the diffused cancer cells in my breast so they'll get clear margins.  Surgery for me is April 26.  Chemo wasn't fun but with the supportive meds the side effects were manageable.  I'm 51.  My chemo was slightly different than yours.  I had the taxol first (along with a trial drug called Sutent) and then did weekly AC.  I kept working through the first 4 months but I listened to my body and my emotions, which were getting very tired, and went on short term disability at Christmas.  I'm feeling much stronger and it won't be long before I'm back to work until I take another leave for surgery.  It's going to take some time before you're OK with this diagnosis -- at least that has been the case for so many of us.  But you will get through it and be fine.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2010 06:50AM AnacortesGirl wrote: There ought to be someone out there in the field who can give a more concise answer.  But I'll tell you what I know. The different tests are explained on this site under Symptoms and Diagnosis: http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/types/ ACS also talks about them but I think the explanations are so-so. http://www.cancer.org/docroot/CRI/content/CRI_2_4_3X_How_is_breast_cancer_staged_5.asp?rnav=cri Initially I had both a CT and a bone scan.   The reason I got a CT was two-fold.  My symptoms indicated a quickly growing cancer and potential vascular involvement through the skin.  So the onc wanted to see if the cancer had spread to other organs.  The second reason was it was a requirement for the trial I went on - to confirm that I was locally advanced and didn't have mets. The bone scan was standard for my onc.  It clearly outlines the bones and any mets (or arthritis!) "lights up" and is easy to see. In my trial I went on to have multiple PETs.  Different machine and different contrast material.  It was checking for glucose uptake - cancer cells are very active so they have high glucose activity.  This was used to monitor the effectiveness of the chemo trial.  I'm sure I wouldn't have had this test had I gone through standard AC-T.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 04:52PM AnacortesGirl wrote: First, I would like to say congratulations for being almost 5 years out.  That is very meaningful to me since I just finished active tx and I'm trying to get my life back.  Everyday I have a little more energy so the idea of getting to say "I was dx'ed 5 years ago" sometime in the future seems like a real possibility. I had it easier than you.  My kids are adults and I have a wonderful DH to talk with and he gives me great support.  When I was in the midst of it all I would think about ladies like yourself.  I have a lot of respect for what you have done. I completely understand what your feelings and how hard it can be to relate to ladies with DCIS and stage 0.  I have, and continue to have, trouble understanding where they are coming from.  At one point I thought about posting but I just didn't have the courage so I'm glad you did.  The anchor that keeps weighing me down is that my sister died back in 2005 at 52 -- she was initial dx'ed with stage IIIa ILC.  She was never tested but I'm sure she was also BRCA 2+ since both my mom and I tested positive. You would think that I would be more understanding since my mom was dx'ed a month before me at stage I.  And this was her second bout.  We couldn't get her records from her first dx 30 years ago but it was probably stage 0 then based on what she can remember.  Since she lost a daugher she has a lot of guilt about her early stage dx. So what's wrong with me that I can't be more compassionate and understanding?  In my heart I know that if I  had been dx'ed with stage 0 or I instead of III I still would have been a basket case.  I would have been so scared that the docs weren't doing enough.  That I would end up going down the same road as my sister because of the lack of preventative measures.  So you would think that I could be more accepting of their concerns and fears. But it just isn't where I'm at right now.  I keep hoping that we will get a cancer support group in town so I can spend more time around other people with different stages and even different cancers.  I know I could use the therapy time talking and listening.  In the meantime I stay away from those forums because I know that I am not the right person to be trying to support those ladies.  So my way of dealing with it, for now, has been to stay away.  But this is one of the reasons that I plan on getting more involved with cancer related charities in town once my own life is back on track. Thank you for having the courage to post and give me a place to air my feelings!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2012 10:02PM AnacortesGirl wrote: Hello from a fellow stage IIIc'er.  It a lousy place to be, isn't it?  I've spent a lot of time researching and googling.  Sometimes I'd find some pretty ungly stuff.  If you google pleomorphic and stage 3 you'll see what I mean.  But, after 2 and a half years I'm still here.  And I really believe that I have many more ahead in my life. Go ahead and cry.  There is absolutely nothing wrong with that.  We do what we have to do.  For some of us, that means looking in the void and see nothing but negative.  But when we pull back, we see all the wonderful things in our life and we find the courage to go on.  You're in the middle of chemo and you've been let down because you thought things would get better with Taxol.  I can understand that because I heard that was the "easy" one.  Well it wasn't easy for me. I had neuropathy, terrible "fogs", everything tasted terrible (that when you realize how many food commercial are on tv!), rash, hoarse voice and had two transfusion.  I actually did Taxol first and then AC.  AC was better just because my taste improved but I still had to have 5 more transfusions.  Chemo is rough.  My goal was to get through the week.  But when it got really bad my goal was to get through the day.  I did it.  So can you!  It will get better.  But unfortunately, it requires time. I also wanted to respond to your comments about cancer treatments.  We are much, much further than 20 years ago.  We're further than we were back in '99 when my sister was dx'ed.  The supportive drugs are greatly improved and allow more women to continue with chemo.  In the past, they would have to stop because of nausea or low counts.  A friend of mine had luekemia 20 years ago.  She had to be hospitalized the entire time she was going through chemo (6 months!).  Now we have AIs for estrogen positive.  For those of us with BRCA2+ they have Parp Inhibitors.  I have a list from someone who used to post -- I'll try to find it and add it to this post. Don't believe the conspiracy people!  Their simplistic view really burns me.  Breast cancer affects many, many people.  Including (or the families of) pharmaceutical execs, researchers, oncologist, etc.  But cancer is a mutation of a cell, the very basic form of life, not easily separated from the good cells.  If you would like to understand the struggle of finding a cure for cancer I would recommend "The Emperor of all Maladies: a history of cancer".  I found it very interesting. Keep on, Posy!  You're getting close to the end of treatment.  Right now, time is your friend.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 09:56PM AnacortesGirl wrote: I don't know if this is any help.  But for the mets that I can reach, I can find them with pressure from my fingers.  For instance, I have a spot on my right femur that will hurt at times.  The general pain is about the size of my palm a couple of inches below the ball joint of the hip.  But if I just use my fingertips, then I can point to the specific spot where the lesions is.  And if I put some pressure on it, it will continue to radiate pain for a while after I move my fingers away.  This is the same with the lesions on my iliac and sacrum.  The generalized pain will come and go, but the specific pain when I find the right spot is always there.  I hope someday that it will go away due to the right treatment Definitely talk with your onc.  It is such a learning process to figure out how to describe the aches and pains let alone figuring out what is causing them.  I hope you can get some relief and stay on the Femara.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 12:17AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Sharon - That's great that you've moved to the 6 month visit schedule!  I wish I could send you to my PT.  She's been wonderful!  Most of my issues have been shoulder related but I did start of with mild lymphedema.  I got a couple of sleeves right away.  We wanted to nip it in the bud.   Once the fluid starts building it gets harder to move it out of the arm and into the body.  I'm not sure why Jenn's doc didn't want her getting one - it worked well for me to prevent the fluid from going down into the arm and start building.  I just had to make sure that I put it on first thing in the morning when the swelling was down. Self message is easy to do - just like Jenn described.  Just a light touch is all it takes to get things moving.  But going to a PT that specializes in lymphedema is a really good idea because not only can they show you the correct way to massage (starting with the trunk and moving to the arm), they can also give you a series of exercises that increase the lymphatic flow.  They can find the "plugs" and clear them so the fluids will start moving again.  By the time you're done you'lll know how to take care of it yourself.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2014 04:47AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I'm so glad I wrote down my memories and feelings because it really has helped me work through what happened and has made it easier to let it go.  After talking to a friend today I am afraid my credibility has been shredded if I would try and talk to a patient advocate.   This is a small town and I should know better than to share things without doing some serious filtering.  But I was still upset and so I told my friend about the "walkabout".  I downplayed it in my previous post because I felt I had already made my point in the original post and didn't want to continue to do anymore hospital bashing.  I am not going to go into any more detail about it, but it was another case of inconsistency.  What was OK one day was very, very wrong on the next day. I thought the person that I was talking to would keep my story confidential because she had her confidentiality broken just a month ago.  A fellow club member recognized her voice as she and her doctor talked about her cancer biopsy in the outpatient surgery room.  That club member proceeded to let everyone else in the organization know about her cancer.  My friend was extremely upset as she had planned on keeping her medical issues private.  She told me today that she had repeated my "walkabout" story to her many friends that work at the hospital and that they were appalled that the hospital had "lost" me.  I don't like drama.  I did not want her repeating to others what I had told her.  I was venting at the time and I had thought she would empathize with how I was loudly reprimanded, with first and last names being used, just like her privacy had been violated. She will remain my friend but the filters are back on -- full strength.   I do appreciate the feedback and the empathy from all of you.  This has just been a very confusing episode and I truly hope it is never repeated.  Should I end up in the hospital again and start having issues then I think I will contact the advocate to see if we can understand why there is this lack of good communication.  Or maybe I will just go to Seattle.  But I am not going to dwell on this any longer.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2013 02:34PM AnacortesGirl wrote: There are two test processes performed with the "basic" testing. Then there is a 3rd test, the one that costs $700, that is a very detailed test. Can't remember exactly what the test does but if you googled the BRCA testing process you could find it. As you found out, not all insurance plans will pay for that 3rd test. For instance, medicare was not going to pay for my mom's testing but my plan would have paid for it. We didn't need the 3rd test - our mutation was found on the second test. The majority of the mutations are found with the "basic" testing. Since you had that much done, I think it's safe to say that you are negative. You should have been given a report from Myriad Labs that provides the results. The results are something like no mutation, a variant, or mutation. My testing was back in Nov of 2010 so I don't remember a lot of the specifics. If you were positive, although it sounds like you are not, it could potentially affect your chemo. For instance there are some studies that indicate the platinum chemos work well with BRCA cancers. So your onc might use cisplatin or carobplatin. Depends on what the onc is comfortable with and what each ladies' situation calls for. If you don't have any paperwork from Myriad Labs then you might want to call your onc's office and ask for a copy of that report. They are the only lab that does the BRCA testing in the US. (Just don't get me started on Myriad labs and why they are the only lab in the US and how they managed to patent the BRCA gene. I'm looking forward to the day when the lawsuit is finally heard by the Supreme Court.)
Posts.Title: BRCA1 BRCA2 Do you know? debbiej redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 11:26AM AnacortesGirl wrote: It will get better!  Even my onc told me to take it one day at a time.  I already knew it but hearing it from him helped.  His real message was don't expect too much too soon.  Keep plugging away and when the treatments are done your body will have time to heal.  As the body heals it helps the mind to heal also.  Most of your brain is there for all those bodily functions and activities.  The poor thing is working overtime trying to react to the insults being thrown at it from the chemo and rads. It is amazing how we can come back out of these depths and be ourselves once again. Don't forget to monitor your red blood cells.  Normally, one of the first symptoms of anemia is unstable emotions.  Fatigue is usually second.  I found it helpful to get copies of my blood counts so I could know where I was at and give myself some slack if the RBCs were low.  Chemo hit my counts hard so in addition to the daily neupogen I also had to have multiple transfusions.  It has been a slow recovery for my bone marrow but it's finally there and so am I. I have become a believer in anti-depressant.  Tried Lexapro and Wellbrutin.  The onc and I settled on Paxil and it has really helped carry me through this.  Some day I'll stop taking it but for now that thought is still too scary.  Being normal is still too new -- I need more time.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2013 12:11PM AnacortesGirl wrote: Laugh, cry, hope - that is the basic formula. I enjoy relays. It brings together a large group of people who have this huge common thread of cancer. But there are also a lot of people who haven't dealt directly with it. They may have family members or friends who have been stricken but they weren't close enough to see what it looks like. Then there are the people who have tremendous stories of what they have faced and the courage that they live with. Last year's speaker was the town's school superintendent who had been dx'ed with prostrate cancer. He was an example of someone who went through the "I'm going to die from this" to the cured endpoint after surgery. So how could his story be interesting? Well, his dx immediately hit the paper so everyone knew about it. He was in shock mode before it was understood how much cancer he had or if it had spread yet he already had people looking at him with those pity eyes. But it was also the school year that, after his dx, we lost a first grader to leukemia. Needless to say that hit him hard now that he had a personal taste of cancer. So his talk was short on his cancer but focused on the community and how it rallied around him but even more important, around the lovely girl to make her short live as full as possible. Ended with how his cancer was a minor thing because of the research and learning how to cure his prostrate cancer. How research continues to give hope for these young kids and someday they will be cured and get to finish their schooling and have a full life. So that is an example of how you don't have to have the worst cancer story at the relay. It is about how cancer does make us cry - it hurts. It is about how this have improved, that the support and the research are making a huge difference. That we are seeing the difference right now - it's not this goal that is so far out in the future that no one is benefitting and may never benefit from it. We, as stage IV ladies, are seeing the changes right now with longer lives. But it is not enough. We need the research that is going to give us a cure for all the cancer types and stages. Does that help? We can PM if you would like to talk more. I would also suggest that you be put into contact with the ACS staff person who works with the Relay Committee. That person should be able to give you all sort of assistance (if they are worth their salt!). What I personally like about ACS is that they try to keep their staff numbers low, their advertising low and put most of their money back into support programs and research. There is lots of information on the ACS website and they are open about how the money gets dispersed.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 08:00PM AnacortesGirl wrote: I'm sorry that you had progression.  But it is good news that it is staying in the bones and not moving to any organs.  There are still many treatments for bone-only mets.  Most ladies go through many different treatments, some work for a long time and some don't work at all.  We are all different. Did he give you anything for the pain?  Tylenol and ibuprofen can work sometimes but it would be wise to have something stronger on hand for those days when the pain is worse.  Before I got bone mets I was under the impression that the bone pain would be constant and at the same level of pain.  It wasn't until I got bone mets myself that I found out the pain does come and go.  Sometimes it's not too bad and then there will be periods when it is pretty bad for a while.  It is definitely not constant! I hope what he gives you for anxiety works, also.  And I really hope the chemo treats you nicely.  Or at least as nice as chemo can be to anyone. It's nice to hear from you!

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 05:15AM AnacortesGirl wrote: "I shouldn't be buying stuff like this."  What???!!!  Hey, with all we have to go through spending some money on wigs should be the one this we indulge in because it's for fun and makes us feel human again.  Much better than all those other purchases at the pharmacy -- my pharmacist is nice but I know him way better than I want to. I'm 51 also.  My old hair was gray -- I actually liked it because it had a real nice silvery frosted look to it.  My first thought was to match it but I couldn't see anything in the catalogs or online that appeared to be the same color.  That's when I decided I had to go to a wig shop and see the real deal.  I just couldn't count on those online color swatches.  I also knew that I didn't want the human hair because I just didn't want to deal with the care and styling.  I've ended up with 4 wigs for now.  One from TLC (free, through a local hairdresser), one from the Looks Good, Feel Good class and two that I bought.  I really need to take the 2 free one (one red, one brunette) to my hairdresser and get them trimmed up so fit my face better; they are both too straight and need some more 'zip".  But the other two I bought.  They are synthetic and cost about $125.  One is blonde and the other a bruntte with frosted streaks. I had decided that since I was going to lose my hair I was going to try to have some fun with it.  I was always very conservative with hair before but I considered chemo as my excuse to get as crazy as I wanted to.  Still can't say I'm crazy (no pink or oranges for me, thanks!) but having me wearing red hair is a pretty big stretch from where I used to be. All the people I work with know what I'm going through.  And so they get a kick out of it not knowing what color I'm going to be the next day.  And the two wigs I bought -- I can't believe how many comments I've gotten from others who have no idea that it's a wig and I'm going through chemo.  They just figure I've had my own hair worked over.  It's been a morale booster. I was very happy with the wig shop I went to.  She pulled some for me and then I told her a few I wanted to try.  I'm so glad I didn't try to do this out of a catalog.  And there's a chance I might go back and get another one.  It is so cool getting curls without a perm!

Posts.Content: May 25, 2013 08:14AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I hope you can get the accelerated benefits from the life insurance. That money is non-taxable. Unfortunately my employer changed the accelerated clause to say that life expectancy has to be less than 6 months. I'm not going to try for that money - luckily I have good LTD coverage which gets us through this. When you apply for SSDI you definitely want to demonstrate that she was disabled from the time all this started. But they will consider the pay received in that time period so it will reduce what you receive and if you get a check for SSDI backpay then 80% of it is taxable. Using vacation days for when you are ill are not regular pay so I was reimbursed through SSDI for the 5 weeks of vacation I used instead of sick days. I was working two days a week and using 3 days of vacation. Turns out this was below the threshold of the amount of hours Soc Security looks for to consider the pay as "fulltime" so they considered this as not working. It was complicated stuff so I have forgotten most of it. I was also lucky that my LTD insurance company paid the fee for Allsup to file for my SSDI. All I had to do was supply the timesheets and pay stubs. Normally their fee is 30% of what you get from SSDI in backpay. I would have done it on my own had it not been free for me.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2013 11:58AM AnacortesGirl wrote: For claiming to not know anything about the BRCA mutation you are right on target! The BRCA 1 mutations tend to be triple negative (ER-/PR-/HER-) like yourself. While BRCA 2 tends to be ER+/PR+/HER-. Of course there are always exceptions. The mutation is passed by a parent; it is found in both males and females. It definitely affects the risk of breast cancer but also increases risks with ovarian and, in men, prostrate plus a few more cancers (very small risk increase). So the main reasons to be tested in a person who is already dx'ed with breast cancer is for treatment purposes. Because I was BRCA 2+ I had a double mast (right breast was completely clear) and had my ovaries/fallopian tubes removed. But if you are positive without cancer then you are in a high risk group for testing and may decide to remove breasts or ovaries as a preventative measure. They continue to research so there are trials out there that may be used as treatment for BRCA positive ladies. Insurance paid for my testing. Medicare paid for my Mom's testing. We had to see some genetic counselors first. They reviewed our family history and gave us a risk percentage that we might have the mutation. Some insurance companies use that risk number to decide if they will pay or not. It is expensive. Lots of information on this subject in BCO and FORCE.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2010 10:05AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Not the same situation but sort of similiar.  My daughter-in-law was 6 months pregnant when I got my dx.  I felt so bad about it -- I didn't want to take anything away from the happiness that she was feeling about having her first baby (and my first biological grandchild).  So I told her outright how I was feeling.  That I didn't want my treatments and health issues to overshadow her pregnanacy.  That her baby and it's upcoming birth were more important and definitely a very special time.  I think this helped our relationship because she would make sure I knew about showers or shopping trips (she lives 2 hours away) and would invite me.  If I was feeling well then I would make it, if not, then I stayed away because I didn't want to be a distraction.  I wanted the spotlight on her. But I will say that the news of my dx hit my adult son and daughter harder than I expected.  The rest of the family and my friends took it much better.  In hindsight I understand that this hit them out of the blue.  Mom has always been there, never had any health issues and for the first time they were face-to-face with the reality that someday I won't be there.  I finally got through to them that I expected to be around for many, many years!! I don't know if any of this applies to your situation -- I wanted to share in case it helps.  You are not alone!

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 03:01AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Janette - I'm guessing that the 1958 in your name is your birth year.  We're the same age and share the BRCA 2 + mutation. I was 2 months into neoadjuvant chemo when I got my results.  We already knew that I needed a modified radical mast on my left because of the cancer and I was trying to make the decision about the right.  Once I got the results I immediately decided on a BMX.  Surgery was last April.  I'm so glad I had the BMX.  Not only did I never want to to through chemo again I was also concerned about having a "good" arm.  The lymphedema in my left arm is very mild but I have to watch it carefully and I'm going back to physical therapy after the first because I'm still having issues with internal chest wall scaring that keeps me from having good movement.  But my right arm is 100%.  The BS let me decide if she would do a SLN or not and I told her no because removing even one lymph node can cause lymphedema issues.  The right breast biopsy was totally clear and the nodes looked good. Last October I had the laproscopic BSO (removed ovaries and fallopian tubes).  For that I went to a Gyn surgeon who specializes in hereditary cancers.  They did an extensive biopsy where they slice the tissue in to many thin specimens so they can look throughout the tissue for cancer.  And during surgery they do "washings" to look for cancer cells in the abdomen.  Everything was clear. No recon for me.  Don't want it.  I love putting on my forms in the morning and having perky breasts all day.  Totally comfortable! Then I when it's time to relax I put my boobs away and get into my PJs.  I'm very happy with everything I did.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2014 01:49PM AnacortesGirl wrote: Cathi, Sorry I am so slow getting back to you -- between trying to finish off the gall bladder and moving on to a new treatment it has been a whirlwind. I do not regret trying this treatment at all.  My only regret is that it didn't keep working for me.  The platelets never got too bad, but the cutoff to withhold treatment for this particular trial was 100,000.  Hopefully your trial protocol would be a little more reasonable at something like 75,000.  The worse my platelets got was 96,000 so I lost a week of taking the drug until the platelets got back over 100.  I only had to do labs every 30 days (except when we were watching my platelets).  Veliparib is relatively gentle on the blood counts.  When I was in the hospital after my gall bladder surgery my hemoglobin did get down in the sevens for some reason so I got a couple of units of red blood cells.  I'm not sure why that happened since it had been staying constant in the low elevens. The only really hard thing about the drug was that initial month of nausea while my body got used to the drug.  But taking Zofran, Compazine and Ativan got me through the 3 weeks that were the worst and then just Compazine and Ativan for the last couple of weeks. There have been some very good results for some ladies (both BRCA and trip neg) who have taken this drug.  My trial onc had at least one lady that was still on it after 20+ months.  She was one of her first patients to try veliparib.  This drug is definitely more tolerable than chemo.  It might give you a good break to build up some strength.  And there is a chance that you will have a good response.  If I were in your shoes I would definitely want to give it a try. As for me, I just got a carboplatin infusion this last week.  I talked my onc into trying the carbo first.  But after two cycles if it isn't doing anything than we are going to try cisplatin.  I'm pretty concerned about the chemo because when I was doing my stage III chemo I had to have 8 transfusions for my red blood cells.  I'm just afraid that I won't be able to tolerate the hits to my marrow.  Oh well, we'll see how it goes.  We've tried everything we could for the BRCA2+ except for some hard core platinum chemos.  So this is the last shot at a treatment that is really focused on my cancer.  After that it will just be the eeny-meeny-minnie-moe method for choosing chemos. Wishing you the best of luck and I hope you can do the veliparib! Christy

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2011 03:10AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Polyana, I completely understand why you are looking for more information.  I also understand why your onc doesn't believe in percentages.  Percentages are hard facts.  They are just guesses.  It's been said many times that they only percentages that matter are 0% and 100%.  But we are human.  And most of us need something to help us look to the future.  For me, I wanted to hear the percentages so I would know how hard I have to fight.  I had one onc tell me my odds for getting mets within 5 years was 50%.  I use that as inspiration.  But some women don't take that type of news well and they because depressed and basically give up.  Our oncs worry about us so they try to be very careful about the information they relay because they want us feeling positive and acting positive.  So I understand why the onc doesn't believe in percentages. So what are your percentages?  First off, they really can't be broken down to IIIb.  Stats are much broader than that.  They lump all stage III together.  And they also lump all the women together irrespective of treatment types (different chemo, different surgeries, different radiation).  They also lump together women who exercise, don't exercise, take their hormonal drugs daily, skip or stop their hormonal drugs, have weight issues, have no other health issues, have many other health issues, etc.  So to know your future who really have to look at YOU.  Calculators and studies just can't do that. I've looked at a lot of information trying to better refine my own stats.  I have to say, what Claire posted the other day, seems to me one of the most accurate stats we have as a stage III group. "For those diagnosed between 1995-2004, it was 74.1%" And that study group is from 7-16 years ago.  I'm sure that our survival rate has gone up since then.  And it still makes a big difference when you factor in your specific disease, health and attitude. Your tamoxifen makes a huge difference.  And when your done 4 years from now there will be more advances in research.

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2012 04:00AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Your post brings to mind a couple of thoughts I had when trying to decide what to do. I was a technical team lead for a small group (5). Two people were what I considered young and needed some coaching. In one of our weekly status meeting one of these people made the comment that I don't answer my emails anymore. It really hit me to core when she said it. One of the items that I wanted to work on with her improve how she did her troubleshooting before she shot out emails. She send one out and before you had a chance to hit Send on your reply she had sent the "never mind" email. But the truth was that I was just ignoring her emails and not working with her. That's when I realized that I was giving my team the leadership and support that they needed. Time to go out on full-time LTD. Four months later I come back and my manager and I were of the same mind. Stay away from the team lead role and just work on two projects that was individual work and utilized my 25 years of knowledge. Just 3 days a week. Tried this for 5 months. The last month I was only working half days because of the fatigue and headaches. I knew it was time to go. And I realized that it was the right thing to do for my company and for some individual who was going to get a good paying job with a future. Time for someone else to have the wonderful opportunities that I had.

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2012 02:52PM AnacortesGirl wrote: I was hesitant to take Ativan except for certain situations such as scans. But one day, at the end of my workday, I was talking to a co-worker and started to feel a little strange. I attributed it to the cold that I was trying to get over. Hopped into my pickup and proceeded to drive home. Kept feeling more out of it as I drove along. Started to have a hard time focusing. I only had a 12 minute drive home but 4-5 blocks away from the house I had to pull the truck to the curb because I felt like I was going to black out. I thought for sure that the reason I was having trouble breathing was because I was getting pneumonia. I was so disoriented that I couldn't call anyone on my phone. A father and son on a bike ride stopped and ended up calling 911 for me. I ended up in a full blown panic attack. Hands and feet going numb, fighting to stop from blacking out and finally terrible pains in my chest. They got me calmed down at the hospital and ran the usual scans. Turns out my sinuses were completely blocked. Between talking to my co-worker about my health (he has a wife with similar health issues) and the feeling that I was getting from my sinuses/head woosiness it was all I needed to set me up for a panic attack. After experiencing that I promised my onc that if I started feeling weird like that again I would take my Ativan and have my DH come and drive me home. I always have Ativan in my purse now and if I think I'm getting anxious then I take one. There is no way I want to go through that experience again. And I haven't got hooked on it yet, which used to be my biggest worry.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 11:51AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Hi Frances! Welcome!  I'm so sorry you got dx'ed with a second primary but I'm glad you found us. I'm another one who found out the port placement is important for women who don't have much fat.  I eventually had to have my original port removed and a smaller one inserted.  The first surgeon didn't even tell me that there are different sizes so that was great relief to know I was getting a smaller one.  The second surgeon took time with me to figure out the best place and I still have it almost a year after my last chemo.  Doesn't bother me at all! I'm one of those that loves having a port.  I do not like IVs.  But don't be surprised if it hurts for the first week after it's been placed.  They told me that after it's inserted they can use it right away.  Well, in my case they were going to get their hand bit if they tried!  After a week it was fine.  EMLA is lidocaine in a cream.  Some infusion centers use lidocaine before they access the port (i.e. stick the needle in) and others don't.  The place where I go they give you a shot of lidocaine first -- it's a very small needle so they tell you it's a misquito bite.  But I've also used the cream.  You slather it on about an hour before and just cover it with plastic wrap so it doesn't get on your clothes.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 11:04AM AnacortesGirl wrote: At this point, a week feels more like a month because the waiting and uncertainity is so rough!  But in terms of gathering all the information (scans, biopsies, appts) it is still early to understand what the right plan will be for your mom.  I like the suggestion of looking at the onc guidelines.  They may be confusing since you're still new to the terms and treatment protocols but that's OK.  It can stimulate questions which should be written down and taken to the next appointment.  Are you participating in the appointments?  Or is the information you are getting is what your parents are verbally telling you?  It is very common, since this dx is such a shock to our emotions, that information is not absorded well and we hear what we want to hear.  Your mother is entitled to ask for the doc notes from all appointments along with the scan, blood and path reports. If you are going to be involved then it would be a good idea for your mother to make sure your name is on the HIPAA form which allows you to have access to her records. A second opinion is always, always a good idea.  Ideally, the second opinion just confirms the confidence that you've already bestowed in the first team of docs.  Sometimes it can be a completely different recommendation.  But the docs expect it and sometimes insurance companies will insist on it.  As nowords says - it's all about trusting the team and moving forward.  You don't want to look back with regrets.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 12:20AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Please disregard the information that you got about kerosene. I don't know how anyone could claim it would rid anyone of cancer in any healthy way. Ingestion of kerosene is fatal. Kerosene is one of the products that is derived through the distillation of crude oil. As an IT analyst I worked at a refinery. We would bring in crude oil and use different methods to pull out gas, deisel, jet fuel from crude oil. After these products are pulled out of the crude, the remaining crude gets cut into other products that are less used. One of these is kerosene. I don't know where people come up with crazy ideas like this. It is sad that anyone would claim a toxic chemical can be injested as some sort of home remedy. Chickadee - I'm confused about your comment that the copper depletion is in a Phase II trial which makes it unavailable to patients. I'm a patient on a Phase I trial. Did you mean that you cannot get the treatment as a patient unless you are on the trial? It's early morning here and maybe I'm not reading that correctly.

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 10:39AM AnacortesGirl wrote: So much of your post sounds very, very familiar.  I completely understand where you are coming from with the family history, the call backs, and as you're getting older you think this will be the year.  I can't tell you how many times I had that same thought: "Just bring it on already and let's get this over with."  Especially after my sister was dx.  BTW, my mom's second primary was 30 years later.  But, having said that I understand the fear, I also realized I was wasting energy on this fear.  Somewhere in my mid-40's I was able to let it go and not let it interfere with living my life.  I like what Fidelia says about putting this energy into something positive.  I strongly advise you not to google and read the boards.  It just doesn't help.  IF you get diagnosed then you will find that your cancer has a specific presentation.  That is when using the boards is helpful because now you are trying to find help that relates to your specific cancer.  There are too many different types and variables for this research to be of use to you.   I"m very glad to hear that your doc is proactive and wanted you to have an MRI.  For those of us who are at high risk due to family history it's a powerful tool.  Had my doc sent me for an MRI then I'm positive my cancer would have been found much sooner. I'm very sorry you had the problem with your vein and the contrast.  I've had 6 MRIs since last July (4 of them were to monitor my chemo tx) and I know how stressful they can be.  To add a bad experience like you had adds even more stress to the procedure.  Talk to your doc and make sure that prior to your next MRI that your given Ativan to relax you and make the stress more bearable.  It's a very reasonable request and it will help.  I'm hoping you have clear results.  And please let some of the fear go into living the life you have right now.  You have a good doc who is doing the right things.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 12:50PM AnacortesGirl wrote: It may be helpful to look at your Dad's side also.  Although my Mom is where I got the gene mutation from, it was her father that passed it on to her. Her dad died from prostrate cancer. How long ago was your aunt told not to do the test because it would throw up a red flag on her insurance?  In May 2009, the GINA (Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act ) went into effect.  This prohibits medical insurers from using genetic testing as a pre-existing condition or denying coverage.  It does not cover long-term care, life, or disability insurance. There's a good article on Medscape that you could read. You need to create a free account to access the article: http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/704508

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 09:41AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Goodness!  You noticed the date and I didn't!  Wow.  Two years.  It's a nice way to start my day - thanks!! It was a rough week but I think (both hands in the air - all fingers crossed) I might be turning a corner.  Still have a mild headache this morning but my thinking is clearer and the funk is easing. Looking back, the aromasin gave me major hot flashes, problems sleeping, swelling in hands and feet, joint pain (some days nothing - other days it really slowed me down) and the icing on the cake was that my feet become too sore to do any walking other than around the house.  It was like the tendons were tightening and wanting my feet to curl. But this all happened gradually and the first 6 months, except for the hot flashes, were pretty much trouble free.  I had been on 20 mg Paxil prior so we just continued that.  To take care of the hot flashes he put me on Neurontin.  One in the morn and one at night.  Trouble sleeping, even with the Paxil, so increase the Neurontin to two at night.  A few months later and things are starting to go downhill again with the sleeping and so we try 2 Paxil a day - doesn't do much - so back to 1 Paxil and 3 Neurontin at night.  That's were I was for the last two months before I hit my limit on the headaches and hand/feet pain.  Now I'm taking at least 1 Vicodin a day for the pain, sometimes two. So I see him and the plan is that I stop the Aromasin, wean myself off the Paxil (Paxil doesn't play well with tamoxifen), maybe cut down on the Neurotin if the hot flashes reduce as the Aromasin leaves my system.  Then I start back up on Tamox and Lexapro.  Effexor was the first choice but I had a face rash after taking that for a week once before so it's off the table. So this Tuesday I started the Tamox and Lexapro.  But I was an emotional wreck when I was in his office.  So we also added an appointment with a counselor next week. In the meantime, the funk, fuzzy thinking and headaches are driving me bonkers.  Last Sunday I was sitting here on the boards thinking that I really needed to get away from the PC and go take my shower.  Wait - my hair is wet. I already took it and I had no memory of it.  That really spooked me.  And I think my actions were spooking my DH, too.  So he gave me the OK to do whatever I wanted with the Neurontin depending on how my hot flashes were doing.  So I stopped it.  Zip - nada.  And because I stopped the Aromasin the hot flashes are no longer a problem.  No Neurontin has really improved the fuzzy thinking. But the headaches continued, just milder and slightly different than the original killer ones.  We have have a PA and parttime nurse at my company so I went to those guys to ask for some aspirin.  The nurse heard my story and she firmly believes it's the Paxil that is causing my remaining problems.  She tells me that she has seen people who need to wean themselves over the course of 10-12 weeks.  Literally down to taking a shaving off the pill for the last week. So right now I'm only taking Tamox, Lexapro, and Vit D.  We'll see if I can get past the last of the headaches and start getting back some energy again.  I also hope that I click with this counselor.  I just have a lot of stress right now with the med changes, guilt for alll the work I'm missing and trying to help my father/mother with their lives since dad has dementia and it's just about time to get him into memory care. I'm really tired of drugs and SEs!!

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2013 01:13PM AnacortesGirl wrote: That sounds so much better! I'm glad that your onc is still looking at options. I thought of another possibility. Have your mets been tested for androgen? Androgen is the female version of testosterone. My bone and liver mets have been tested and both are postive. This means that another option we may use in the future is casodex. Casodex is the anti-testosterone drug that they use on men for prostrate cancer; other anti-testorerone drugs are also being looked at for the treatment of mets. Being postive for androgen receptors is not correlated to estrogen positive. So this treatment option is also a possibility for triple neg ladies.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 01:45PM AnacortesGirl wrote: Sharon, I've got to add my 2 cents.  Note: I say 2 cents but it seems like I can't ever write a post that's less than $1.95 worth of words but the total value is about 2 cents!  BTW - whatever happened to the cent sign?  They were on the old typewriters! I have tried and tried to feel better.  I still go to the physical therapist.  I do my exercises.  I take my pills. I try not to take the vicodin until I really need it (tylenol, aspirin, aleve, motrin don't help).  But no matter what I do I have my good days and bad days.  And lately there have been more bad than good. I am not a hypochondriac and I am sure that you aren't either.  It's not our imagination.  We get pains that we've never had before.  Sometimes for a day and sometimes for weeks.  I was hoping my getting off Aromasin would bring me some relief.  My feet are a little better and my hands a little better but it's been 3 weeks off and I still get headaches, swelling in my hands, on/off hip pain and today my lower back is as tight as a drum.  The only good thing is that I'm weaning myself off paxil and I haven't noticed any deteriation of my moods. I don't have answers.  I've been struggling to find answers for myself.  I just wanted to let you know that I'm in the same boat.  Why can't we have  just have a positive attitude and we get our old bodies back?? Grrrr! I just went through the same thing on the vacation bit. I was feeling pretty bad but I was scared to go to the onc and find out negative news right before we left.  Specially because it was a wedding for my late sister's daughter.  I wanted cancer out of my mind during her special day -- I knew she was wishing her mom could be there and I didn't want to be a reminder. Well, hubby insisted I make an appt.  He was right.  Everything is negative.  That's when the onc said to stop taking the Aromasin and we'll switch to something else after a 4 week reprieve.  I also asked for something besides Ativan since that does nada to help me sleep.  The Xanax works much better for me so at least I have a crutch if it's one of those anxiety nights. The vacation would have been much worse if I hadn't gone and I was still thinking those "what if" thoughts.  My body didn't improve much but my attitude did.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 04:47PM AnacortesGirl wrote: I had no response to neoadjuvant so we tried carboplatin even though we had clean margins after surgery (2 mm).  My marrow could only handle 5 of the 12 weekly doses.  But I feel good that I was able to get 5 more. Just this week I downloaded the NCCN's 2010 Guidelines for Breast Cancer Patients.  They used to only create the guideline document for the oncs.  The guideline for locally advanced still doesn't say outright that adjuvant chemo should be given if the tumor doesn't shrink.  Just "individualized treatment".  I know that this isn't quite your situation but it just goes to show that the minute you have anything different (such as your intercostal lymph node) then it generates discussions with the docs.  That's a good thing! My feeling is go for it.  Your docs are looking out for you and trying to kill any cancer cells that might have escaped.  It sure would be great if we had a test that would tell us if they are all gone or not after we finish the standard treatment. Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 09:30AM - edited Feb 14, 2010 09:30AM by AnacortesGirl "EVERYONE is learning on this road."  Another great way of summing up what we are going through.  Throughout this topic there are some great comments like this. I agree with the original rant.  Being respectful.  It doesn't matter if you're stage x posting on stage y or if you are a fellow stage 3er posting back to another stage 3er's post. In my mind "posting" and "advice" are not synonymous.  There are topics that aren't about asking for advice -- they are just though general daily life topics that all stages deal with.  I love diversity and on those topics I enjoy reading all the different perspectives.  Some I agree with.  Some I can't relate to.  Then there are those topics where women are looking for help.  Often those topics are related to their stage.  If for no other reason, because of their mental state.  These are the topics that it is so important to pause and consider if your stage/experience is really appropriate.  As an example, if a women is talking about the fears and questions about follow up scans she receiving as a 1 or more year survivor then I don't feel I can add much.  Even those I'm also stage 3 I haven't been there emotionally or medically. I've seen and experienced criticism from stage 3er to stage 3er.  At least I took it as criticism.  But I guess that's a point I would like to make.  I'm in treatment, I don't sleep well and I'm still trying to get used to the idea that my dx is the same dx that ending up taking my sister.  So please consider where I'm coming from before you take a stab at me because I do think very carefully before I post.  And it's a different emotional roller coaster for the women in the initial or later phases of this journey. I don't criticize when I read something I don't agree with.  But if it's advice and it' medically incomplete or wrong then I will add my comments.  I want to help other women just like I've been helped.  But I try to be respectful.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2013 12:35PM AnacortesGirl wrote: MrsM - There have been two kids that made me really stop and realize that sometimes things are happen that are completely unexpected and uncontrollable. The first was my niece from my first marriage. She was a year younger than my DS. Both my SIL and both went on to have another daughter so there were 4 cousins (her two and my two) and they spent lots of time together. This niece however, was just a little different. I don't really want to say that she had an evil streak, it wasn't that dramatic, but she would do things to her sister or against her mothers wishes that seemed kind of unnerving. But she also seem to not understand why she did those things because she clearly wanted to please her mother and she loved her sister. She is now an adult and my DH believes she has Asperger's Syndrome. Her mother is a wonderful, caring person. She struggled with her daughter -- she wanted to be the best mother that she could and she tried so hard to help her daughter be more "normal". Clearly this was a case of something that was totally uncontrollable. Back then we barely new about autism let alone something like Asperger's. Or maybe it was something completely different. We don't know but she is remote to her mother and continues to turn people away because of her hurtful social actions. The second one is one of my husband's grandsons. His daughter is a very loving mother and does a great job of keeping a stable family life (two more sons who are younger) with lots of support for the kids and their interests. But this kid is scary. I'm not exaggerating. My DH and I have talked about it quite a bit. He has always had an infatuation with guns (they are a hunting family but this goes beyond the normal interest) and he was always seeing animals, bugs, birds, whatever moves, as something to kill. He also has been unnaturally assertive. He was about 5 years old and visiting us; he and I are in the my flower garden and when he wasn't squashing bugs he was telling me how he could cut all the flowers down. When I tried to explain how I didn't want that and that I enjoyed the flowers it didn't make any difference -- he just looked me in the eye with a flower in his hand telling me that he could pull this out right now. I picked him up and we went back into the house where his mom was. When DH and I have heard about young kids getting into hunting accidents or even diliberate killings we have wondered out loud if this kid is going to be on the news one day. He feels like a sociopath to me. But talking about this to his mother is not going to happen. She believes he is a good kid who just needs more growing up. We don't share her confidence. To see these children who are different from the time they are developing in their second year through when they become adults (in the case of the niece) has been an awakening for me. These are not problems that are solved by drugs or changing their peer group or any other external fix. And the mothers (both kids have very loving stepfathers) are stable, good people. I just wish they had worked with a psychologist or psychiatrist a long time ago.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2014 06:31AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Are you having problems with fatigue and/or depression?  Taking 3 meds isn't unusual.  Xgeva is a bone strengthener so it is common to take it with the many cancer fighting treatments.  If the SE of fatigue is experienced it is usually in the day or two following the injection.  In my case I've been getting Xgeva injections for the last year and a half and I don't even notice any extra fatigue.  But I've been dealing with fatigue ever since my initial chemo ended after my stage III treatment. I personally haven't taken the affinitor/aromasin treatment but I know that some women find that combo hard on the SEs.  If you are experiencing fatigue then I would suspect this treatment first.  But this is where you need to talk with your onc and weigh the benefits against the side effects.   Depression is common for all of us.  It doesn't matter if it is being caused by a drug or just the reaction we have to our chronic disease.  I strongly recommend that you talk with your onc and try an anti-depressant.  There are lots to choose from and it is amazing how they can turn around a person's outlook.  I'm on Lexapro and it makes a big difference in my daily life. I take  the following: velaparib (PARP Inhibitor to fight cancer), Xgeva (bone strengthener), Lexapro (anti-depressant), methadone (pain med), oxycodone (pain med), prilosec (indigestion), temazepam (sleep aid), neurontin (eliminates hot flashes), ritalin (combats fatigue), along with some vitamin D, stool softener and calcium.  I don't really like taking so many meds but they each have a purpose and they keep me in a good place.  I've tried cutting back on the pain meds, the neurontin, the prilosec and each time it was a failure.  It just got things out of balance and it would take me a week or so to get back to being on an even keel. So my message is that the number of meds isn't necessarily important.  What really matters is what the meds do to you and are you needing some other meds to counter the side effects of the treatment.  Talk with your onc and let him know your concerns and your issues.  Fatigue is a hard one and for the most part we don't have good answers.  I do take a small dose of ritalin to try and counter the fatigue but for the most part it has just been something that I have to accept.  But you might have other options.  Hopefully your onc can get some answers for you. Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 10:12AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I had sleep issues from the get-go with chemo.  I started with taxol and I'm sure the problems on that regimen had to do with the stronger steroids I was getting.  My onc wanted me to stay to the non-addictive sleep meds/aids such as melatonin, tryptophan and benadryl.   The only one that worked was bendryl and since I was having the allergy reactions (rash, running nose, etc) then that was my preferred drug.   Towards the end of the 12 weeks I was getting fatigued enough that I was actually getting an occasional 8 hours of sleep or able to take a nap on the weekends. Had a 2 week break and now I've been on AC for a month.  Sleep is worse than ever even though the RBCs are down to 9.1.  The weird part is I feel fine during the day.  But during this time I've been getting up at 1, 2, 3 in the morning.  Regardless of when I go to bed.  And I'm lucky if I can get a 30 min nap.  Just talked with the onc yesterday and he's suspecting an underlying anxieties.  Very possible -- I'm the type to push those feeling down.  So last night I took my first lexapro.  It's also additive drug (like ambien & ativan if used on a regular basis) but we want to see if it's anxiety.  If it is, then hopefully my sleep will improve.  Then when I finish chemo, then I should be able to withdraw off of it and still be able to keep my sleep patterns.  I'll know a lot more in a week or two.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2013 12:13PM AnacortesGirl wrote: There are a lot of choices out there, some interfere with out treatment meds, some interfere or have a negative interaction with our support meds. And some work better for some women than others. And to top it off, some meds have a potential to reduce some of our SEs. Two drugs that I am aware of that can be helpful for SEs are Effexor (reduces hot flashes in some women) and Celexa (reduces neuropathy flare ups for some women). Unfortunately I got a rash from Effexor so that one wasn't an option. It does sound like you should consider a daily anti-depressant med. I started with Paxil which was great for making me feel more positive and energetic. Unfortunately it interferes with tamoxifen so I had to get off of it. Then I discovered the nasty side of Paxil -- it is an extremely hard drug to quit. The side effects of headache and emotional vulnerability were terrible. Then it took me a month before my Lexapro kicked in. So that was two months of hell that I don't want repeated. I really liked Paxil but I would stay away from it. My onc just switched me from Lexapro to Celexa. It was an immediate switch -- taking the Lexapro one day and the Celexa the next. He wanted me to try it to see if it helps with my neurapathy. I've been on it for a little over a week so it is early to say that it definitely helps. It appears to be helping. I also have ativan in the med cabinet. I have had a full blown panic attack (had to go to the ER) so I know had bad those can be. The ativan works very well for me if I start to get that anxious feeling. I also use as a preventative measure before especially nerve racking appointments and before many of my scans. I used to measure my scans by a "one ativan" or "two ativan" scan. An example of a two ativan scan for me is the brain MRI. Makes me very, very anxious. My ativan is also .5 mg. It doesn't work for me to take ativan as a nightly sleep aid. I got better results from 10 mg of melatonin. Now I am on temazepam for sleeping. Hope this helps.
