Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 10:33AM AnacortesGirl wrote: That news really sucks.  I sure hope it really is small this time.  I'm sure you would welcome any good news about it. My left mast was a given with my dx.  And I was leaning toward a bmx even before I got my BRCA result back.  For the same reasons that you have already listed.  First and foremost, I didn't want the possibility of lymphedema on both sides.  I wanted to know that I would have 1 good arm in the future.  And the thought of going through this again should the good side turn bad just turned my stomach.  I knew that I would regret my leaving the good breast should that happen.  Well the BRCA results cinched it. I have to say that I have been very happy about getting a bmx and no recon.  They didn't touch the lymph nodes on the good side -- I didn't even want the SLN because we didn't see anything on the MRIs and I wanted them left alone.  The right breast biopsy was completely clear.  But I don't regret having it removed!  I was strongly advised against recon for at least a year after tx.  The bmx was last April.  From the minute I put on the mast bras and forms I just loved the way they felt.  Having nicely shaped boobs that were higher up on the chest again felt great!  I got to pick my size and, if for some reason I want to change, I can go back and get a different size.  Can't just walk into a store and get a bigger set with recon! I have a friend who had a single mast and hasn't had her recon done yet.  She hates her bras and form.  But we've compared notes and we think it's the difference between a matched set of forms versus trying to match a form with the real thing.  So she is looking forward to getting the recon surgery done. As for me, tomorrow is my ooph surgery and I hope that is that last time I go under for a long, long time.  I'm tired of surgery.  I'm 52 and the forms give me the look I want in public.  At night I get to take 'em off, get into my jammies and kick back.  My DH doesn't mind one bit.  He just wants me sitting there relaxing with him for many years to come.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2010 08:03AM AnacortesGirl wrote: While she is healing it would be a good time to go and get another opinion from a different oncologist.  There are so many options for handling nausea and low blood counts.  What did they try?  I had a lot of issues with my reds and ended up with 7 transfusions but they did the trick.  I also took daily neupogen shots to keep the white cells up (neulasta is the other option).  Were they tracking the metabolic panels for liver and kidney functions when they did the blood tests before chemo? Unfortunately we are all different and some cannot handle the standard chemo regimens.  But there are different chemo drugs and different ways of administering them.  For instance my AC was done as a weekly Adriamycin infusion and a daily Cytoxan pill.  Nausea was handled with Zofran and reglan - no real issues.  Fatigue just meant I was in bed at 6-7 every night and slept till my normal get up time of 5:30. I was 51 when I went through my chemo and in good health.  I feel that I'm about 75% of where I was last year before starting treatment but I'm just finishing radiation and am still on a low dose chemo.  It won't be long before I'm 100%.  I believe it's reasonable that your mother, who started with good health, should be able to get through this tx without all these major health issues.  Is the doc so focused on eradicating the cancer that he's forgetting about the human patient? It doesn't feel comfortable knowing that the cancer is still inside her but she has to be back to a healthy state to get through the surgery.  Sharon has a good question -- have they been tracking the effects of the chemo on the tumor with scans (MRIs or maybe UltraSound)?  If not, then I'd definitely be looking for another onc.  It was almost 6 weeks after my last chemo before I did surgery and there was no changes in that time.  Even with my grade 3 cancer it wasn't spreading that fast.
Posts.Title: Discouraged Soconcerned AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 06:58AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I wouldn't consider too weak to stand and bad hand/foot pain normal complaints.  I had the bad hand/foot pain and had to take vicodin throughout the day for almost a week.  My onc decided it was time for a break in tx because it was affecting my quality of life.  Amazingly, it cleared up in a week and never came back as severe. My thought is to not waste the energy blaming the onc.  Some women just don't handle chemo very well due to their biology.  But it does seem that it would be worthwhile spending that energy on finding a different onc to get a second opinion.  It may not bring any new information into the equation.  But the relationship between a cancer patient and an onc is a long term commitment.  Even after the initial tx there are years of visit back to the onc.  You want to have a doc that your mother feels she can talk to, will listen to her and will respond with her best interests in mind.  If you can get an appointment set up with a new onc then be sure and ask for copies of all her scans, lab work and doctor notes.  Ideally the scans should be both the notes and the electronic copy of the actual scan.  Hand deliver them to the appointment.  It will ensure that the new doc has them for review.  You mention shots for her blood levels.  There are two types.  Neupogen and Neulasta stimulate the white blood cell production.  Procrit and Epogen are used to stimulate red blood cells.  However there are studies that indicate the use of Epogen or Procrit may stimulate cancer growth.  My onc will use them in limited use but not as a regular supportive drug. Is your mom on an anti-depressant?  If she is able to handle it, after all the other issues, it might make a real difference for her going forward.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 03:12AM AnacortesGirl wrote: seacretgardn - Surgeon often refer to 3 level of axillary nodes.  Levels 1 and 2 are located in your armpit and right below.  The third level is on the body side of the shoulder and tucked under a muscle.  Every women has a different number of nodes.  My surgeon said that she had seen as few as 5 and as many as 50.  In my case I was getting a modified radical mast which meant they were taking levels 1 and 2.  Turns out to be 17 nodes for me.  During surgery the doc used her fingers to feel the 3rd level.  Since she didn't feel anything of concern she left them alone.

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 10:02AM AnacortesGirl wrote: My platelets took a nosedive at the end of AC.  I was supposed to do 27 weeks but I stopped at 26 because, in addition to the hits I was taking on red and whites, the platelets went down to 57.  But 3 weeks later they were back above 100 and were fine by surgery.  Now I'm on low dose carbo and it's the low platelets that have caused problems again.  Changed from 3 weeks on, 1 week off to 2 weeks of chemo then 2 off.  I asked the onc if there were any options other than a platelet infusion and he did mention a drug that is a platelet stimulator (like Neulasta or Epocrit) but I don't remember the name.  He didn't say too much other than it wasn't warranted since giving me a break from the chemo will allow my counts to recover.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 02:50AM AnacortesGirl wrote: This thread makes me realize that I need to have two sets of last wishes. One would be vague -- it would be used if my DH is still alive. We have, and will continue, to talk about what we want in the event of my passing. When it comes to having a funeral, celebration or nothing at all - that will be up to him since he would have to do some of the organizing, letting people know, etc. I won't care since I won't be there (at least not consciously). But I should have another set of last wishes for my adult kids if DH passed before or with me (such as a car accident). Luann - I think you've been given some great suggestions. I understand why it would be easier to talk to all the kids at one time. They all get to hear the same words, you don't have to repeat yourself many times, and if any kids have any questions or objections than everyone knows the answer or what the future issue may be. But I do think you need to lay it out for them. Even as older adults it is very hard to come to a common ground on such an emotional topic as a parent's passing. Young adults would have a harder time. Definitely decide where you want to be buried and let them know. They are young - careers or spouses may take them far away from Ohio, Michigan or even the US (both my kids are in Canada). I had already decided to be cremated and have spent a lot of time figuring out if I wanted my ashes in a cemetery or not. I have finally decided that I want them spread into the wind. That way my kids will be able to visit me whenever the wind blows no matter where in the world they might be.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2009 06:37AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Ditto on more consultation.  I ended up going to 3 different oncs and after they saw my reports, reviewed my health and heard my desires they all had the same recommendation. I just finished posting to a topic that I started where I was trying to understand if locally advanced breast cancer was a subset of stage III.  The answer is that it's not subset and it can has some various in definition but as a general rule it's all stage III and stage II with lymph node involvement.  But in the course of posting, thinking and researching I realized that my real question was why aren't all these women getting neo-adjuvant treatment like I am.  So, even though I'm now on week 8 of chemo, I finally asked my onc along with doing some research on my own.  It was a good conversation and it re-confirmed my initial decision. For me, neo-adjuvant fits my tumor presentation (er/pr+, grade 3, moderate proliferation, ILC, ) and it also fits how I personally want to attack it.  And since my health has always been good (don't even have allergies) there was no reason not to go that route.  Since I have multiple tumors, including 1 under the nipple, I have been told that breast conservation is not an option.  And due to family history I don't consider breast conversation an option.  But if the tumor is reduced because of chemo it is going to make me feel better knowing there's a chance that any cancer cells that might have escaped the lymph nodes are also being killed.  With surgery first I wouldn't know that and, because of my family history, I need to have that knowledge or I will forever be wondering in the future.  Even though it probably won't have any significance statistically on my long term prognosis.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 08:06AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Here's another thought for everyone.  I was tested positive for BRCA2.  The stats for getting bc vary according to the specific mutation found.  In my case, the mutation gives a 87% chance of getting bc by age 80.  So for me, and the others in my family who inherited it, this trumps all the other studies out there for percentages. But what about the other 5 genes that they feel are contributors that they can't test for yet?  Or the ones they don't know about yet? Maybe those are just as high in the stats? I believe these comments are right on track.  We don't know if those women were following their treatments.  We don't know if they have gene mutation that skews their re-ocurrences.  Quality of life is so important.  If we use common sense and feel good about what we are doing I think we're more likely to stick to treatment.  And feeling good about what we are doing just adds to our positive lifestyles.  Guilt will just erode it. If my chemo allows me to enjoy one glass of wine at Christmas with my family around me then I'm going for it.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2013 09:45AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I am so sorry you have joined our sisterhood but I am glad that you found us. When does the numbness go away? That is so hard to say because it is part of the uniqueness of each of us. For my initial stage III dx I was completely in shock for a month. Couldn't think and was only able to function at a very low level. But I came out of it during the second month. It was pretty much the same when I was given my stage IV dx. I am so glad that you listened to your gut and didn't accept the "wait for 6 months" answer. What you described sounded like classic lobular cancer. Doesn't get picked up on a mammo; the best diagnostic tool is the MRI. I am also glad that you are getting the genetic testing. BRCA + cancers have some specific treatment tools such as PARP Inhibitors. If you already know the pathology of the breast mass then you can fill in your profile information which will help us understand your cancer and women with similiar cancers can step up and talk about their treatment paths. If your cancer is lobular then there is a good possibility that it is slow growing. The grade that the pathologist assigns is a method of understanding the aggressiveness. Normally ILC is grade 1; in my case it is grade 3 and it did change quickly when I decided to go in for my annual mammo. It was the pain that I had that was the clue there was more going on when the mammo didn't show anything. It will get better as you learn more about your cancer and the many treatment options for your situation. You are still in the waiting room and that is the hardest place to be.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2010 06:55AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Suz - Can you do some shopping for me??  I hate clothes shopping.  After about 15 minutes I'm ready to give up.  If it's a good day I can last for 30 minutes.  jessamine - There have got to be quite a few different factors that contribute to how much we drain.  Amount of liquid intake, type of surgery, amount of exercise, our weight.  After surgery on Apr 26 I'm less than 20 cc on two of the drains and at 50 cc for the third.  I don't think I've been drinking as much water as I should be and I definitely haven't been exercising much.  I try to do for myself when I can when it comes to reaching for things, putting things on, etc.  But so far walking has jarred my left side too much so that's been pretty minimal.  Maybe today a walk will be OK.  But no reconstruction for me -- that probably another reason my fluids are so small since I didn't have the additional trauma.  And I'm thin. I've been surprised that the bruising wasn't worse.  I had a pretty good sized hematoma from my exicisional biopsy and it took many weeks before it disappeared.  I'm not seeing anything similiar from this.  I'm also pleased that I'm getting sensation back in the skin of my left inner arm.  The BS said that she was able to save 2 nerves and a blood vessel going to the shoulder so I should expect full functionality after it's healed.  However I wouldn't be surprised if the numbness on the chest remains.  But that's OK with me.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2010 08:31AM AnacortesGirl wrote: jessamine - Good news for you on getting the drain out!  Now you can start healing.  I took my first soaking, relaxing bath yesterday and it sure felt good. paxton - I understand where you're at having to go back on chemo.  After my path report showed no/poor response to chemo my trial onc wanted me to go back on xeloda, cisplatin or carboplatin.  But my regular onc said let's wait till we get my CT/PET scan done to see if I have any evidence of disease (an earlier PET showed something in my lungs and chest wall).  So I won't know until next Wed if I have to go back to chemo with rads or if it's just rads.  My neoadjuvant chemo was weekly and lasted for 27 weeks.  So I my countdown started with a big number.  You can do 3 more!!  You've got the strength and you'll figure out how to cope.  I saw that in another post you mentioned that you are anemic.  That was a major problem for me and it really, really affected my attitude.  I ended up getting transfused with red blood cells 6 different times during my chemo.  But it did wonders for my attitude.  Now the RBCs are still low put they are slowly going up on their own. Also consider antidepressants.  I've tried 3 and currently am on paxil.  It has really helped with keeping me from the big lows.  And I'm finally able to say "that tasted good!".  My taste buds had really been zapped and my appetite was very poor.  I think the paxil is finally pulling me out of that also.

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2014 11:49AM AnacortesGirl wrote: When I was stage III I did my chemos in the reverse order because of the trial I was on.  So I did Taxol first, along with the trial drug (sutent - very similar to avastin) and then did the second half of the AC part, Adriamycin and Cytoxan.  The AC regimen was much, much easier for me.  I had already lost my hair but I got my taste buds back (not 100% but at least I could eat).  I also gave myself neupogen shots to keep the white blood cells up.  However I did have to have red cell transfusions.  But obviously my blood marrow is pretty lousy for regenerating cells since I only had one infusion of carbo and I'm still going in for more platelets and red cells.  Overall, I felt it was a very doable chemo but just had an early bedtime of around 7:00 pm. Best of luck!!

Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 03:28PM AnacortesGirl wrote: leisaparis - I wondering if you are experiencing cording?  You can do a search and find a lot of discussion on the topic in this forum. All - Well I mentioned that my BS didn't call back on Monday with the path results.  She did leave a message Wed with some of the information but that we could talk about the lymph nodes during my visit on Thursday.  So, as I feared, she wanted to wait to give me the news.  Turns out I had 14 of 17 lymph nodes with cancer.  Since I had already gone through neoadjuvant chemo we really didn't expect this.  It moves me from stage IIIa to IIIc.  And it looks like there is going to be more chemo in my future. I've already posted on the stage III forum and have gotten some good advice from those ladies.  Unfortunately some of them have been there before me. Took my DH and I a few days to absorb it so I've been absent from the boards. The good news was clear margins.  And it was really good news to hear that no cancer was found in the skin or nipple.  I had had some symptoms that were suspicious of skin involvement so it was great to hear a positive.  Absolutely nothing in the right breast so my decision to leave the lymph nodes alone on that side was the right call. Healing is going well.  One drain left but it really doesn't bother me.  Much better than 3!! Like many of you I also have various sensations as the nerves are coming back.  The burning and heat rash feelings are the worse.  I'm still taking an oxycodone to take the edge off.  However I woke up a couple of nights ago because it so bad and ended up taking 3 oxy's before it finally got better.  I'm just glad that I'm getting nerves and feelings back so I'll put up with this for a while. My DH has been great!  Not only does he see the scars but he's the one who's been stripping the drains, changing the dressing, putting on the aqua guards so I can take a shower.  I absolutely love the man!

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 07:32AM AnacortesGirl wrote: jessamine - I just wanted to jump in and say that I totally understand about the drain.  I finally got mine out last Thursday - just shy of 4 weeks.  It was getting so frustrating.  One day it would be at 28 and then the next it would go up to 40.  Start going down again, get below 30 and jump right back up.  I never got it to stay below 30 for 2 days in a row.  On top of that, I needed to schedule my rads simulation, get a CT/PET and start PT but I couldn't do any of those.  I was stuck in this limbo and couldn't move forward with any treatment. The BS who did the surgery is in Seattle and she gave me the OK to have a local surgeon take it out so I would have to make the 2 hour drive down there.  So my onc set up a visit with a local surgeon and I brought my drain charts.  I was all prepared to have him look at the chart and say no.  Much to my surprise he took one look, asked if it had been leaking around the bandage (yes) and said that it was blocked and needed to come out.  It had a lot of junk in the tube that we hadn't been able to strip out and I guess he figured that if it had been able to drain normally I would have been below 30.  I haven't had any problems with fluid build up after it was removed. Now I didn't do recon so I don't know if that matters.  But the BS had told me that it's not unusual for neoadjuvant chemo gals to drain longer.  So I chalked it up to that.  I'm assuming that you're close on volume also.  Do your best to get them to take it out.  Question the effectiveness of it.  Tell them it's leaking.  Tell them that it's making you depressed.  Whatever you can think of!  Enough is enough.

Posts.Content: May 30, 2010 08:52AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Paxton - What a guy!  That smile just oozes love!! algreach - My PT is having me massaging my scar to loose it up.  I just put my fingertips on it and gently move the skin up, down, left, right and then move to the next spot and repeat on down the line.  She said this can be started after the first 4 weeks of healing are complete.  It gently tears apart the skin layers so they can start being independent again. The other thing I found out with my first visit is that I was being too aggressive on my stretching.  She says with cording that if you stretch too far then it actually causes the tendon to respond by shrinking again.  So I just get to the tense point when I stretch now and no further.

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 11:10AM AnacortesGirl wrote: MartyMart - I love the lesson that your Dad handed down to you. Hopefully I have done the same for my kids. Whether they are labelled "mistakes" or "misfortunes", they are part of living life and the only way they won't happen is if you are no longer living. So understand that these mistakes/misfortunes are going to happen and it is all about what you learn from them and how (or if) it changes your life. However I would like to gently challenge what you said about the regret of not having another child. If you could have been guaranteed that this child would have ended up being the support and companion for your first child, then I would call this a regret. But since you cannot predict anything about what a second child may be like, I would call it a wish for another child who could have been a support and companion. Had you had a second child you have no idea how the child would be either as a youth or as an adult. I have seen too many instances of other people who seem to be good parents, living in a supportive community and good lifestyle yet their children ended up being nothing but heartbreakers. As parents we do the best we can but there is an innate uniqueness in each child and sometimes that uniqueness borders on sociopathic tendencies. Any one of us could give birth to a child who could have very little conscious or be apathetic to other people's needs or hurt. Or their peer group has a stronger influence than anything the parents exposed the child to and they end up with drug issues or other problems with the law. We can wish for a child that will be who will be the adult that we can be proud of, but sometimes the ability to raise that child into the adult we want is taken out of our hands. Please don't regret that second child. But leave it on the list of wishes.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2013 01:21PM AnacortesGirl wrote: What wonderful, thoughtful topic! My belief is that you can only regret those things where it was up to you to make a decision. However we do have the ability to "wish" that things were different where we didn't have any control. The reason I believe this is important to differentiate is because guilt, which can be a very negative emotion, can often be tied back to regrets. For instance I do not believe we can regret getting breast cancer. We had no control over it. No decision making where we could say "hmm, I think I'll skip my veggies and have another drink even though I know this is going to cause me to get breast cancer". Unfortunately I do think there are women who feel guilty about having the disease. Even though they made no decision to have, or not have, breast cancer. Here is another example of how guilt can be tied to regret. My daughter, when she was 18 and just out of high school, told me that she had bought tickets and was going to Hong Kong for a month. Alone. Had I taken the stance that I was totally against it and that she was going despite my belief that it was dangerous and foolhardy, then I have no doubt I would have had regrets when she returned from her enjoyable and safe trip. And if my attitude against her taking this trip and acting independently had caused a rift in our relationship, I would have felt regret and guilt. The way it turned out was that I recognized that this was a decision that she had made and I did everything I could to support her even though I was scared to death. We talked about it and she offered to call me everyday that she was in Hong Kong. It was a wonderful compromise and it helped both of us feel closer. She did withhold the information that she was going to Hong Kong to meet a girl friend that she had met through the internet. Turns out her "gut" was right about that friend and today they are domestic partners in Canada. Her Hong Kong partner is a wonderful lady and they are very happy together. No regrets and no guilt. So I have spent time throughout my life looking back at the things that I thought I felt that I regretted or felt guilty about. Such as my first experience with college. My parents paid the tuition and room/board for my first semester. I left South Dakota and a boyfriend behind and moved to the coast to go to shcool. Mid-semester I couldn't take it anymore (or at least that is what it felt like at the time) so I backed up my belonging, got on a plane and went back to the South Dakota boyfriend. Didn't tell my parents. But they found me by calling the boyfriend's parents. I was soon pregnant and married a few months later. Took me a while to no longer feel guilt or regret for what I had done. But I finally realized that I did what I did because of who I was "at that time". Of course I wouldn't have done that again as I grew older. But at that time it was the decision that seemed right. More importantly, as I grew older I talked to my parents about it and let them know that I had grown beyond such a selfish act and that I appreciated the way they did not shut me out. Instead, they reached out to me. It was an amazing growing experience for me and had a lasting, positive effect on the rest of my life. So I don't have many regrets. I've worked through them in my mind and have come to understand how I did what I thought was right at the time. But I have also appreciated how those incidences have helped shape me into a more understanding person. However I do have wishes. I wish that somehow I could have met my current husband back when I was 20 and he was 30. What a better choice than the lazy bum I picked back in South Dakota!

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2014 08:07AM AnacortesGirl wrote: bottkota, Well I took my last veliparib this morning.  I had a bone and CT scan yesterday and since today was the last day of the cycle, I had my last veliparib after my blood draw and then had my appointment with the trial onc.  Unfortunately I have another new liver lesion and the new lesion from last month has grown.  They can also see that I have new bone mets.  So I am off the trial.  No new package of veliparib to bring home. So let me back up to the beginning.  About 7 months ago I signed up for a Phase I trial using an Extended Release formulation of veliparib.  It has a strange protocol where the dosage that you get is based on if you were one of the first or a participant coming in much later in the trial.  Because I was the first at Seattle Cancer Care, I was only on 200 mg a day.  It was very easy to take and I had no problems.  But the dosage was not effective for a clinical response.  So after the first month my onc was able to modify my protocol to give me the immediate release formulation and she increased the dosage to 400 mg twice a day.  That is where I have been for the last 6 months. The first month of the 800 mg/day dosage was tough.  It causes significant nausea until your body get used to taking it.  For me, that took about 6 weeks.  To begin with I was just taking zofran.  But two weeks in, I called the nurse and told her that I wasn't getting enough relief from the zofran.  So they added compazine.  This seemed to be enough to get through it.  I started getting some SEs from the zofran so as soon as I was able, about week 4, I dropped the zofran and just used compazine and ativan. The only other SE that was affecting me were my platelets.  It is very common for veliparib to hit the platelets hard.  Everything else, CBC and CMP, were holding stable.  Although while I was in the hospital recovering from my gall bladder surgery they decided I needed 2 units of Red Blood cells.I'm not sure how much of that was due to the veliparib versus the surgery.  Or maybe a combination. No other SEs.  That part was great. I started with scans (bone and CT) and then got a CT every other month.  From the beginning we will seeing either stable or a very slight reduction.  I was also seeing my CA 2729 drop by 40 points every month.  It started at 188 and got as low as 78.  But the next month it rose by 7 points and then it rose by 40. The reason that I was trying this drug is because I'm BRCA2+ and they have seen such great results with BRCA ladies.  We were hoping for many months of stable or even regression.  I had been looking forward to taking a PART Inhibitor since I was dx'ed stage III back in 2009.  But after 5 months I had a new, albeit very,very small liver lesion. We were even talking about doing radio frequency ablation or some other method to eliminate it.  And the other lesions were staying stable.  But with my scans at the end of this month, it is clear that 6 months is the most I'm getting from a Parp Inhibitor. It is strange the way I'm getting mixed results from the lesions -- some stable, some progressing, a few regressing.  But the oncs are chalking that up to BRCA cancer - the DNA mutation is in evey cell, not just the cells that have cancer. I could have joined the trial that combined veliparib and carboplatin (this was also a Phase I so there wasn't any randomization; everyone gets the drug).  But the last time I used carbo, my CBCs went into the cellar.  I didn't want to risk that so I wanted to join the monotherapy trial. I have the highest hopes that you will see good results.  Except for the nausea I think you'll be happy with the lack of SEs. Are you triple negative or BRCA+?  Those are the only reasons that I familiar with that get benifit from ParP Inhibitors.  ' Wishing you great success! Let me know if you have questions.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2010 11:04AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Not sure why the surgeon would say not to bother with the MRI if you do the excisional.  If they find something in the biopsy than I would think they'd want to do an MRI to see if there is anything else in the breast.  That's what happened to me after they removed 1 tumor during the biopsy. Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2010 09:21AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Each of us are different on what we tolerate and what bothers us.  I don't have any problems with the MRI - part of that is because it is so much better than the PET scans that I've had. At the breast center I go to they have a very comfortable form that you lay face down on.  Your face lays on a hollowed out area so it's just padding around the edge of the face and in the hollow area, where your mouth, nose and eyes are, air is being gently blown.  I've done this locally and they don't have as nice a form and don't have the hollow area.  Not as comfortable but doable.  Your given a panic button in case you need immediate help.  But the techs will be talking to you through speakers and they can also hear you.  The 30 minutes is divided into multiple test that may last 30 sec, 1.5 min, 2.5, etc.  The techs will be talking to you and letting you know how long the next test will last.  So, in case you do have any issues, it is easy to stop, get you comfortable again and move through the next test. During the test the machine will be making very noisy thumping, knocking sounds.  Weird sounds, but I don't find it troubling. Just a warning here.  I was extremely disappointed at my local hospital when I got one of my MRIs.  The techs did not talk to me to keep my informed of how long the next test was going to last or how much time was left.  I just assumed that they would do that so I didn't explictly ask them.  It was on the tip of my tongue and I should have said something.  I find the tech talking to you is reassuring and let's you know that the test is progressing OK and will be ending soon. I have more problems with the PET.  With that scan you lay face up, get velcro'ed so you can't move, and then have to lay there for an hour to an hour and a half.  In my case I'm part of an imaging study so they do 2 30-min scans and 2 1-hour scans.  Three hours total.  Not fun.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2010 07:36AM AnacortesGirl wrote: A couple of things I would like to mention. First, our you being advised to get a hysterectomy rather than an oomphectomy?  The oomph only takes the ovaries and fallopian tubes.  Much less invasive, minor surgery and doesn't affect muscle.  That is the surgery I will be doing.  My thinking is that any problems that my show up in the future affecting my uterus will have symptoms (unlike ovarian cancer) and I will have time to deal with them if they do crop up.  So I'm for the less tramatic surgery. Second, it could make a difference if you know more about your specific mutation.  I am not as familiar with the BRCA1 mutations since I'm BRCA2 but our research found that where your mutation occurs on the gene makes a difference in the percentages.  As an example, here is an except from some research my daughter did based on our BRCA 2 2024del5 mutation : "Another important factor in risk variation is the Ovarian Cancer Cluster Region in BRCA2.  A mutation in this region has been found to lead to significantly higher risk of ovarian cancer. The region begins at nucleotide 3035 and ends at 6629.  51% of families with mutations in this region have a history of ovarian cancer. But for mutations before and after this region, only 29% and 34% have a history of ovarian cancer.  Our family mutation is before this region, so our risk of ovarian cancer is relatively low (compared to other mutation carriers).  But there is a trade-off here.  Mutations outside the OCCR also are correlated with higher breast cancer risks." If there are variations on the BRCA 1 gene then it could be your risks of BC or Ovarian are different from the general statements.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2013 11:30AM AnacortesGirl wrote: Sending more gentle hugs and thoughts your way. I've had two different sessions of rads in the lumbar and pelvic area. Although they finally gave me relief from the pain after each session was over, I dread the thought of doing any more rads. I know it's probably just my head playing games but I feel like I'm going to start glowing after the next dose of radiation whether it's from a scan or rads. Although the rads got rid of the biting pain that I had, after the second session I ended up with an aching pain in my lower back. The rad onc figures it is because the second set of rads overlapped the first area. It is an SE that can happen where it stiffens up the connective tissues. My second set of rads were applied at half dose two times a day to try and prevent this SE but no such luck. So after it was all done I still ended up increasing my daily pain meds. Thankfully, 15 mg of methadone twice a day is pretty much taking care of it. The reason that I'm mentioning this is that you might find you still have some pain after this is all done. But it should be much more manageable and not the type that can bring tears to your eyes if it gets poked in the wrong place. Just a really annoying ache. So a pain doc might be a good thing. Although I really hope the rads just take care of the pain and it becomes nothing more than a memory. I hope the WBCs get strong soon. It must sound crazy to some people that we want to take our chemo!

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2012 11:47AM AnacortesGirl wrote: With my BS I had a follow up after 3 months, then 2 more at 6 month intervals.  She cut me lose after that because I assured her my onc was doing a breast (chest, actually, since there aren't any breasts!) exam. My radiologist did 3 6 month follow ups, again, looking at the chest for any sign of long term radiation effects but the next visit is a yearly. My onc has me on 3 month visits.  Many women go to 6 month follow ups but my onc watches me closely due to the BRCA 2+, no chemo response, pleomorphic cancer cells.  Since my onc has been following me so closely I really felt the other docs didn't need to see me.  Oh well.  He made it clear that he was taking care of me after I was done with surgery and rads.  He chooses to do blood work (including tumor markers) and physical exams.  Scans are performed only if I have a symptom that needs more investigation.  So ask your doc what the plan is for follow ups.  How often, what is going to be done, what to do if your bothered by something (make appt. after 2 weeks or right away?), if there is any baseline scans that should be done, what is the post treatment therapy (hormonals such as Tamoxifen or Femara) and for how long.  Any other things that would help such as Zometa or daily baby aspirin.  Pick his/her brain and bring a notebook to write it all down.

I have vivid memories of the weekend before dx. Our employees association (I was the president at the time) was adding an 80 x 40 deck on our building and we had a two day work party. I felt so healthy running back and forth all day doing various job and I remember thinking how much I enjoyed working like this. After I finished my stage III treatment I never was able to get normal again. Headaches, fatigue, inability to concentrate. After two years and multiple tries at short term disability I had to finally give up and go on long term disability. Now stage IV and nothing has changed. I should be OK since I only have bone mets and after getting 4 of them radiated they are healing with the other one staying stable. So why can some women get back to a good feeling place and others can't?? I'm so mystified. I'm not a hypochondriac and on my good days I get in a few hours of work (yard or house) and it feels great. Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 07:58AM AnacortesGirl wrote: jessamine - I wanted to respond and let you know how I'm looking at my upcoming surgery.  We have some common ground since we both did neoadjuvant and both are BRCA +.  You're stage II but your tumor size is not too far from being stage III like me.  Just don't loose track of our real goal which is to make sure that we don't hit stage IV.  That's why we've done our chemo and why we are doing this surgery.  If we don't treat it now, it will progress.  Our gene mutation will let it happen.  That's an ugly fact but if we keep remembering it, it will keep us moving forward and allow us to step over our fears and move to the point of being NED.  I'm totally in agreement that I don't like the idea of mutilating my body.  Even with all the cancer in my family (most likely BRCA carriers also) I never consider a proph mast.  I don't believe in surgery unless something is wrong.  I do believe that surgery is very disruptive on the system and can through things out of balance so don't mess with it unless it's necessary.  But it is clearly necessary for both of us.  So I have to use this knowledge to give me the strength to step over the fear.  Think of the positives and try to dwell on those.  We have operable cancers (thank goodness!!).  We have made it through chemo.  You can get reconstruction (this isn't an option for me).  Once we have the surgery done we immediately start the healing path.  So different from chemo where each day we had the drugs building up and didn't know what tomorrow would bring.  This gets us two thirds done - only radiation left. I understand the fear and the worry.  They'll be taking out level I and II of my axillary lymph nodes.  But I'm really hoping they won't have to take level III.  But, the positive is that the right (so called "good") breast is also going to be removed and they are not touching those lymph nodes and so I know that I won't have lymphedema in that arm.  I'll do my stretches and exercises and, until I'm proven otherwise, I'm going to assume I won't have lymphedema in the left either. I'm not going to get MRSA.  At least that the assumption I'm making.  Unless it happens, it's not real.  If it does, then I look at the women I know who've had it and saw that they got their antibiotic IVs and did just fine.  If my 85 year old mother-in-law can get past MRSA then I can too. Don't get me wrong, the fears are real.  But you can get past them and know that you are doing the things you need to so cancer doesn't beat you.  Hopefully my surgical date is still good (Apr 26).  I had a PET done through my trial onc in Seattle and they found some things so the radiologist is recommending another CT scan.  My local onc says this needs to be dealt with before surgery.  So now I'm waiting to hear from Seattle.  I don't want to move to the next level.  If surgery is the way to keep that from happening, I'll do it this minute.

Thank goodness for my DH! I only spent one night in the hospital but if it hadn't been for him I would have had to been there for at least one more night.  No way I could have taken care of myself without some help.  And my wonderful SIL, who's an RN, spent the first night with us and helped us take off the outer bandage, change the dressings and showed us how to empty the drains.  We probably could have figured it out on our own but it made me feel much, much better that she was showing DH the right way to do things. I'm really enjoying the sleep I'm getting nowadays.  I only wake up briefly around 3:00 am, take a oxy, then knock off for another 3 hours.  After the sleep issues on chemo this is heaven! It sure feels good getting this behind me.  Just need to heal up -- but I'm thinking that is going to go quite quickly.  Time for more pain meds....

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 03:43AM - edited Jun 3, 2011 03:43AM by AnacortesGirl Take a deep breath and try to relax.  Don't let cancer rob the month of June from you!  You said you feel fine and that the headaches are just the usual.  That says a lot.  But the onc still has to pursue it with scans to verify that she is doing her job.  She sounds like a conscientious onc who doesn't want to regret not having followed up on an issue.  And she also wants to minimize the wait time by having you come in right after the scans are done so she can give you the results. She's probably adding the PET because she expects the MRI to not show any growth.  The PET is useful for catching cancerous cells before they easily seen as a mass on an MRI or CT because it can show the high glucose activity that accompanies cancer cells.  Unfortunately, though, they can show a lot of false positives so they are usually used as a secondary scan.  So the scenario could very well be that the MRI shows no change and the PET confirms that there is no extraordinary glucose activity so it's not cancer.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2014 11:41AM AnacortesGirl wrote: I don't know if this helps but I found a very simplified explanation of the peritoneum: "The abdominal cavity and the entire surface of all the organs in the abdomen are covered in a cellophane-like, glistening, moist sheet of tissue called the peritoneum. It not only protects the abdominal organs, it also supports and prevents them from sticking to each other and allows them to move smoothly within the abdomen." I know that there are actually two membranes, one against the abdominal cavity and one around each of the organs, with a little fluid in between.  I have always wondered if, when they talk about abdominal fluid, is it the fluid in the peritoneum.  I'm not sure. I just hope the havalen knocks down all your mets.  Have any of the mets been biopsied to see if their receptors have changed?  So far we have biopsied my liver and bone mets and found that the liver lesions match my original BC (ER/PR +, Her2 -) and my bone mets are basically triple negative.  So I am on a hormonal (fasoldex) and a PARP inhibitor (velaparib).  It's been 3 months and so far things are going well.

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2010 09:11AM AnacortesGirl wrote: My mom and I were both dx'ed with cancer so my insurance and her medicare paid for the genetic counselor.  As part of the process the genetics department worked with my insurance to get pre-approval so they would pay for the complete set of tests.  They got the OK from medicare to pay for the first 2 tests for my mom.  Turns out the 3rd test, which was a different type of re-sequencing, was not needed since they found the mutation in the second test. In my case the counselor was helpful for clearing the way on the insurance, assisting us in pulling together the family history and then being able to confirm some questions that I had.  But we had already been familiar with risks and had a fairly good background on the gene mutation.  We now have our genealogy with the known family cancer incidences in a program to help us track the medical history. For us, testing positive was a relief since we knew that there was something going on in our family.  Had we tested negative I think I would have had more questions for the counselor to try and understand why so many of us were being affected. Others in the family are now going through the process.  So far I haven't heard of any insurance issues.  The counselor do a good job of clearing the way and acting as a sold reference of information.  There are still a lot of docs out there who hand out bad information -- for instance I have had a doc tell me that only the mother can pass the gene. Wrong! I recommend it.
